rogel.io.fopl.terms

Class Variable

  • java.lang.Object
    • rogel.io.fopl.terms.Term
      • rogel.io.fopl.terms.Variable
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Expression, Unifiable

    public final class Variable
extends Term
    A Variable is a "placeholder" Term, which can be assigned values through a Substitution set. Variables also allow FOPL formulas that express quantified ideas. Every Variable that is constructed is different, even if declared with the same symbolic name.
    Author:
    recardona

    • Constructor Detail

      • Variable

        public Variable(java.lang.String name)
        Constructs a Variable with the given name. If the name is a String that did not already exist within the domain of discourse (defined as a Symbol), then a new Symbol is created.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of this Variable.

      • Variable

        public Variable(Symbol symbol)
        Constructs a Variable with the given Symbol.
        Parameters:
        symbol - The Symbol that represents this Variable within the domain of discourse.

    • Method Detail

      • unify

        public Substitution unify(Unifiable unifiable,
                 Substitution substitution)
        Description copied from interface: Unifiable
        Attempts to find the Substitution that unifies (makes syntactically equivalent) this Unifiable Object with the parameter Unifiable Object, given an existing set of Substitutions. If no such Substitution exists, this method returns null.

        This method is commutative: calling u1.unify(u2, s) is equivalent to calling u2.unify(u1, s).

        Parameters:
        unifiable - the Object to attempt to unify with, not null.
        substitution - the existing set of Substitutions to work with, not null.
        Returns:
        a Substitution that unifies this Object with the parameter Unifiable, or null if no Substitution exists.

      • containsVariable

        public boolean containsVariable(Variable variable,
                       Substitution substitution)
        Description copied from interface: Unifiable
        Checks to see if this Unifiable expression contains the parameter Variable, given an existing set of Substitutions (which may involve the Variable to check for). This method accomplishes what is colloquially referred to as the "occurs check" during unification.
        Parameters:
        variable - the Variable to check for, not null.
        substitution - the existing set of Substitutions to work with, not null.
        Returns:
        true if this Unifiable Object contains the Variable, false otherwise.

      • replaceVariables

        public Expression replaceVariables(Substitution substitution)
        Description copied from interface: Expression
        Replaces any Variable in this Expression with its binding in the Substitution, if it exists.
        Parameters:
        substitution - The Substitution set of Variables created thus far.
        Returns:
        an Expression with substituted Variables.

      • standardizeVariablesApart

        public Expression standardizeVariablesApart(java.util.HashMap<Variable,Variable> newVariables)
        Description copied from interface: Expression
        Replaces the Variables in this Expression with new copies of the Variable that have the same name. The copies are the Variables that have been standardized.
        Parameters:
        newVariables - The set of Variables that have been copied thus far.
        Returns:
        an Expression with standardized Variables.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
        Compares this Variable to the parameter object. The result is true if and only if the argument is the same exact object (reference-equality).
        Overrides:
        equals in class Term
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to compare this Variable against.
        Returns:
        true if the given object is the same exact object (reference-equality).

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Returns a hash code for this Variable. The hash code for a Variable object is computed as the integer addition of the Variable's unique id plus a prime number (31).
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Term
        Returns:
        a hash code value for this object.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a String representation of this Variable in Lisp-style, with a prepended '?' character and its unique id appended with an underscore.

        For example, if the variable name is X, then its String representation will be ?X_1 (assuming only one variable has been declared, namely X itself).

        Overrides:
        toString in class Term
        Returns:
        a String representation of this Symbol.
